history.content:
The text book and lecture both depict only a pre-processing function g and post-processing function h used in reduction from problem A to problem B.  This might be sufficient for the reduction itself, but shouldn't also define a reverse function for each to prove the correctness of the reduction in the reverse direction? 

My understanding of the proof in reverse direction starts with a solution S' satisfies problem B, then to prove the correlated solution S satisfies problem A.  But how we get S for a given S' is not explicitly defined in the diagram. 

Any feedback?
history.subject: The need for the reverse functions in reduction pre- and post-processing
